title: Max Vogrich
text:
Max Wilhelm Carl Vogrich (24 January 185210 June 1916) was an <a href="Austria">Austria</a>n pianist and composer. His most popular pieces are the "Passpied," "Staccato Caprice," and "Valse Brilliante."
Life.
Max Vogrich was born in Hermannstadt, <a href="Transylvania">Transylvania</a> (now <a href="Sibiu">Sibiu</a>, Romania) on 24 January 1852. A childhood prodigy, he was an acclaimed pianist at the age of 14 years. He studied at <a href="Leipzig">Leipzig</a> under <a href="Carl%20Reinecke">Carl Reinecke</a>, <a href="Hans%20Richter%20%28conductor%29">Hans Richter</a>, <a href="Moritz%20Hauptmann">Moritz Hauptmann</a>, Wenzel, and <a href="Ignaz%20Moscheles">Ignaz Moscheles</a>, completing the studies in 1869. From 1870 to 1878 he was engaged in concert tours throughout continental Europe, South America, and the United States. From 1882 to 1886 he was engaged in concert tours and teaching in Australia, after which he went to <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>, where he lived for some time. He died at <a href="Post%20Graduate%20Hospital">Post Graduate Hospital</a> there on 10 June 1916.
His works include the <a href="opera">opera</a>s "Vanda" (1875), "Lanzelot" (1890), "King Arthur" (1893), and "Buddha" (1904); an <a href="oratorio">oratorio</a>, "The Captivity" (1891); the <a href="cantata">cantata</a>s "The Young King and the Sheperdess" and "The Diver"; several <a href="Mass%20%28music%29">masses</a>, <a href="symphony">symphonies</a>, violin and pianoforte <a href="concerto">concerto</a>s, and <a href="sonata%20%28music%29">sonata</a>s, besides duets, songs, and chamber music.
